did.unittitle: Center for Documentary Studies Student Documentary Projects 1980-2010 and undated

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Duke University. Center for Documentary Studies.

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: The Center for Documentary Studies at Duke University teaches, engages in, and presents documentary work grounded in collaborative partnerships and extended fieldwork that uses photography, film/video, audio, and narrative writing to capture and convey contemporary memory, life, and culture. The CDS student documentary projects collection houses work created by students enrolled in courses on documentary studies offered by Duke University in Durham, North Carolina, and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC), sponsored by the Center for Documentary Studies at Duke. The projects focus primarily on the social life and customs of persons living in and around rural and urban areas of Durham, Chatham, and Orange counties, North Carolina. Includes images of religious life, schools, African Americans, college students at Duke University, migrant workers, North Carolina farmers, and the built environment in various locales, chiefly in Durham, N.C. Project formats typically consist of black-and-white photographs and slides, but newer submissions also contain digital color prints and media such as cassette tapes, videos, and CD-ROMs. Oral histories of N.C. civil rights and labor activists and other individuals are associated with certain courses. Audiovisual materials may require reformatting before use. Acquired by the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is restricted. Original audiovisual and electronic media are closed to use. Use of these materials may require production of listening or viewing copies.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
Some of the materials in this collection such as audio recordings may not be immediately accessible as they require further processing before use.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. There may be a 48-hour delay in obtaining these materials.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.p: NOTE: Images are for research use only and may not be reproduced in any way without written permission of creator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Duke University. Center for Documentary Studies. Student documentary projects, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Marlyse Hickman-MacDonald, Edward Holt, Paula Jeannet Mangiafico, Maria Perales, T. Walker Robinson, and Matthew Warren, 1997-2012
Encoded by Marlyse Hickman-MacDonald, Edward Holt, Robin LaPasha, Paula Jeannet Mangiafico, Maria Perales, and Matthew Warren, 1997-2012

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection houses documentary projects created by students enrolled in courses on documentary studies offered by Duke University in Durham, North Carolina, and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC), from 1980 to 2010. Most of the student projects focus on the social life and customs of persons living in and around Durham, Chatham, and Orange counties, North Carolina. Includes images of life in cities and towns, particularly in Durham; rural life; schools and other institutions such as churches and retirement homes, and charitable organizations such as soup kitchens and orphanages; other community centers such as stores, daycares, and laundromats; African American communities and neighborhoods, particularly in Durham; migrant workers; midwives; and Duke University students and campus life. One series of images portrays the Chuck Davis African American Dance Ensemble in Durham. Oral histories of N.C. civil rights and labor activists and other individuals are associated with certain courses. Many of the projects include written reports and essays.

The majority of projects depict Durham area locales, but other cities and towns in N.C. include Chapel Hill, Hillsborough, Raleigh, Seagrove, Wanchese, Cane Creek, Oxford, Carrboro, Orange Factory, Rougemont, Saxapahaw, Salisbury, Northside, Corinth, and Cedar Grove. There are a few photos from Virginia, and there are a few summer projects that come from Boston, Tel-Aviv, and Tennessee.

Also includes grant-supported projects by professional documentarians: Eric Green, Kate Rhodenbaugh, Carolina Wang, and Donna Lennard, and photographic work by Bill Bamberger, a faculty member at Duke.

Black-and-white prints make up the majority of formats, but there are also many slides. Recent additions also include oral histories on audio cassettes and there are a few CD-ROMS associated with projects. These are marked in the folder descriptions. Original audiovisual and electronic media are closed to use and may require the production of use copies before they can be accessed.

The courses were all sponsored by the Center for Documentary Photography, which in 1989 changed its name to the Center for Documentary Studies. Among the faculty teaching courses for the Center for Documentary Studies were Alex Harris, Bill Bamberger, and Margaret Sartor, all of whom have contributed their own documentary work to the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.
Acquired by the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

arrangement.p: Folders are arranged chronologically by course, and student names associated with each class are in alphabetical order by last name. Quoted titles and captions were created by the students; brackets indicate information supplied by the archivist.

controlaccess.head: Subject Headings
controlaccess.p: These are searchable subject entries for this collection. Performing a search on these subjects in the Duke University Libraries online catalog will bring up other related research materials.

did.unittitle: Capstone Project, Certificate of Documentary Studies: Kozin, Jennifer

scopecontent.p: Contains nocturnal portraits in color of Duke University students taken in various locations in and around the Duke campus. Includes two prints of project title and introductory text. Digital color prints measure 13x19 in. and were produced on an Epson 2880 inkjet printer, with Epson Ultrachrome K3 inks on Epson Ultra Premium Photo Paper Luster.

userestrict.p: [Color inkjet print emulsions can be extremely vulnerable to heat, moisture, and human touch. Please use gloves when handling these prints!]

scopecontent.p: Contains "iconic-remakes" of well-known works of art, featuring Duke University students posing as Rosie the Riveter, John Lennon and Yoko Ono, the Girl With the Pearl Earring, Magritte's Son of Adam, Marines raising the flag at Iwo Jima, the Beatles at Abbey Road, and other iconic images. Prints are not captioned. Includes printouts of original icons with text by Jeffery. Digital color prints measure 13x19 in. and were produced on an Epson 28890 inkjet printer, with Epson Ultrachrome K3 inks on Epson Premium Photo Paper Glossy.

userestrict.p: [Color inkjet print emulsions can be extremely vulnerable to heat, moisture, and human touch. Please use gloves when using these prints!]
